Project Objectives: The proposed Project would: (a) strengthen the MOE's capacity to coordinate and implement environmental project; (b) reduce discharge of partially treated or untreated wastewater to the Baltic Sea; (c) restore and enhance the water quality in Haapsalu and Matsalu Bays; (d) improve water supply and sanitation services in Haapsalu; (e) improve the operational efficiency and management systems of the Haapsalu Water Works (HWW); (f) promote management of point and non- point source pollution from the catchment area of Matsalu Bay; and (g) promote environmentally sustainable management and development of the Matsalu Bay and its catchment area.
 - jj - Project Description: The proposed Project would be implemented over four years as an environmental management project for the coastal area of western Estonia. It would consist of a Water and Wastewater Improvement Component (WWIC) and an Environmental Management Component (EMC). The WWIC would consist of: (a) rehabilitation and expansion of the Haapsalu water and wastewater system, including equipment and works along with engineering services; and (b) institutional strengthening and training to assist in establishing an autonomous and financially independent water and wastewater utility in Haapsalu. This would include assistance for tariff restructuring/tariff planning and financial operations. The EMC would consist of: (a) technical and financial support through the MOE for the implementation of selected elements of the Management Plan for Matsalu State Nature Reserve by coordinating and providing funding for identified investments such as access roads, observation towers, information boards etc.; (b) design and implementation of a program of cost-effective activities to reduce point and non-point source pollution of Matsalu Bay from small settlements and agriculture; and (c) support for planning and management of eco-tourism. Project Benefits: The benefits of the WWIC would include: (a) improvements in water quality through reduction of leakages of wastewater into the groundwater and reduction in discharges of untreated and partially treated wastewater, thereby improving water quality in Haapsalu Bay, providing protection for the curative mud deposits and allowing for recreational use of the waters; (b) reductions in operating costs and maintenance requirements in the water and wastewater systems; and (c) improvement in the quality and reliability of the services through establishment of an autonomous water and wastewater utility. The benefits of the EMC would include: (a) strengthened overall project coordination capacity in the MOE; (b) support for MOE's efforts to decentralize project management and implementation to local authorities; (c) expanded recreational use of beaches and waters around Matsalu Bay through reducing pollution; (d) upgrading of environmental management of the Matsalu State Nature Reserve; (e) provision of a basis for a long-term program to control non-point sources of pollution affecting Matsalu Bay; and (f) expanding the opportunities for environmentally sound tourism in western Estonia. Environmental Aspects: Implementation of the proposed Project would have positive environmental benefits through: (a) reduction of untreated wastewater discharges to the Baltic Sea; (b) amelioration of water quality in the town of Haapsalu; (c) pollution reduction in the Haapsalu and Matsalu Bays; and (d) protection of Matsalu State Nature Reserve through effective environmental management. The proposed Project has been placed in environmental screening category "B". An environmental review consistent with the provisions of the requirements of the Estonian "Order on Carrying Out Environmental Impact Assessment" and the provisions of World Bank Operational Directive 4.01 "Environmental Assessment" has been prepared for the WWIC. Supplemental environmental reviews would be prepared as part of the detailed planning process for activities supported under the EMC.
 - iii - Project Risks: The main risks are: (a) the commitment and ability of the Haapsalu City Council to support an independently managed water and wastewater utility which may interfere, inter alia, with the commitment of the Haapsalu City Council to adjust tariffs; and (b) possible resistance from local governments and private landowners to recommended actions aimed at managing point and non-point source pollution in the Matsalu Bay catchment. These risks would reduced by: (a) carefully monitoring the requirements for tariff increases and providing significant institutional development support to the utility to improve its financial management practices; (b) ensuring appropriate project management arrangements are in place in a timely manner; and (c) incorporation of an active local participation process in development and implementation of the proposed management activities for Matsalu State Nature Reserve and the Matsalu Bay catchment.

 I. BACKGROUND A. Country Context 1.1 Estonia is a country with a population of about 1.6 million covering 45,200 km2 on the eastern shore of the Baltic Sea. Ethnic Estonians make up approximately 62 percent of the population, while ethnic Russians at 30 percent of the population, constitute the country's largest minority. During the period of Soviet rule, Estonia had a strong economy based on relatively sophisticated industries and agriculture, and enjoyed the highest standard of living among the republics of the former Soviet Union. Since regaining independence in 1991, Estonia has initiated major political and economic reforms which have brought it from a centrally planned to a transitional market economy. In this process, it is experiencing adjustment shocks common to many economies in transition, characterized by a significant decline in economic productivity and high inflation rates, with the gross domestic product (GDP) declining sharply as a result of the collapse of trading relations with Russia and other former Soviet Republics. 1.2 The Government of Estonia (GOE) has been pursuing economic reform and stabilization, including price and trade liberalization. The liberalization of prices, begun in December 1989, marked the first step in the country's formal macroeconomic stabilization program. Since then, Estonia has been successful in containing monetary and fiscal deficits. Initially, prices increased sharply as the distorted relative prices inherited from the Soviet system adjusted to world levels. Tight fiscal discipline helped assure the success of the currency board scheme under which the new currency, the kroon, was introduced in June 1992. The kroon is fully backed by foreign exchange and has remained pegged at EEK 8 per DM since its introduction. The net international reserves increased 20 percent from 1993 to 1994. The annual inflation rate fell from 89 percent in 1993 to 41 percent in 1994'. The estimated per capita income level in 1993 was US $3,040. Output started to recover in the second quarter of 1993, and the Bank has projected 5 percent annual real GDP growth through the end of the decade. 1.3 The Bank's overall strategy in Estonia is to support the country's efforts to accelerate structural reforms leading to a full transition to a market-based economy and, at the same time, to support efficient investments in high priority sectors to facilitate the return to economic growth. To date the Bank has provided the GOE with a Rehabilitation Loan of US $30 million in October 1992 (Report No. 3525- EE), US $12 million in support of a Highway Maintenance Project in May 1994 (Report No. 3731-EE), US $38.4 million for a District Heating Rehabilitation Project in May 1994 (Report No. 3740-EE), US $10 million for a Financial Institutions Development Project in October 1994 (Report No. 3803-EE) and US $18 million for a Health Project in January 1995 (Report No. 3835-EE). Implementation of these projects is proceeding satisfactorily. 1.4 Infrastructure rehabilitation and development is considered one Estonia's priorities for support. The recently completed Public Expenditure Review, jointly prepared by the GOE and the Bank, highlighted the need to support investments in energy, transport and environmental services, including improved water supply and wastewater treatment. The priority given to investments for environmental services is justified by the need to improve the quality and reliability of drinking water and to address the water quality problems and health risks created by the discharge of partially treated and untreated wastewater to water courses and the marine environment. B. Sectoral Context 1.5 Institutional Settings. The central environmental protection authority in Estonia is the Ministry of Environment (MOE). It serves as the principal institution for the country's environmental policy system, together with the Forest Board and the Fisheries Board. These three institutions form the policy level of the system responsible for legislation, information systems, regulation, and control. The implementation level for environmental monitoring and control work includes 19 County Environment Departments (CEDs), the Institute of Hydrology and Meteorology, 4 regional laboratories, the Nature Protection Inspectorate and the Sea Protection Inspectorate. The MOE is responsible for: (a) developing environmental policy and strategy, legislation, and standards; (b) coordinating management of natural resources and scientific research; (c) organizing environmental monitoring; and (d) carrying out environmental impact assessments, of nationally significant projects. The Chief Inspector of the Nature Protection Inspectorate is responsible for the enforcement of environmental laws, regulations, and standards. 1.6 The CEDs, which represent Estonia's 14 counties and five of the larger municipalities, are relatively independent of the MOE and are considered divisions of local government. T hey issue permits, impose and collect pollution charges from factories, administer the local environmental budgets accumulating from their share of such charges, receive emissions reports from industries under their jurisdiction, and generally try to oversee progress toward environmental goals. The level of expertise varies across CEDs, with those in the larger municipalities usually having a larger and better qualified staff. 1.7 Legislative Framework. Environmental legislation in Estonia is still under developmlelnt. The current transitional status is characterized by a combination of the administrative procedures, legislation, and standards used when Estonia was part of the Soviet Union and some new provisions stipulated by the GOE. The new Constitution of the Republic of Estonia contains a paragraph which obligates each individual "to preserve human and natural environment and to compensate for damages caused by him or her to the environment." Estonia's Basic Law on Nature and Environment Protection was passed in 1990 and important laws and government regulations regarding hazardous waste, solid waste, Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA), and natural resource and pollution taxes have been passed since then. EIA in Estonia is a licensed activity; to date approximately 100 individual experts and firms have been licensed to perform various tasks associated with EIA. The MOE is responsible for review of EIAs when proposed projects are of national significance, while CEDs are responsible for the EIA of projects of local significance. Due to the relative inexperience and understaffing of CEDs, local EIA is not being performed to the standards set forth in the government regulation on EIA. The MOE, with the cooperation of the Stockholm Environmental Institute-Tallinn, is continuing work to improve the quality of local EIA through improved access to information regarding EIA procedures and requirements. 1.8 Most of the environmental standards in use are based on the "Maximum Permissible Concentrations" system developed in the former Soviet Union. The main problem with this system is that there are too many standards (1300 for water quality alone), and many are considered excessively strict and even unattainable; effective monitoring and control of all substances is thus impossible. The
 government regulation "On the System of Charges and Taxes in Nature Management" (February 1990) established charges for the use of natural resources and set forth a schedule of fines levied for violations of environmental legislation. The revenues collected from resource charges are channelled to state and local budgets (the ratio paid to the state budget ranges from 30-80 percent of the total charge). Taxes paid for excess pollution remain in the local budget. Regular pollution taxes are paid to the Estonian Environmental Fund, created in 1983. Its mandate was revised in January 1994 to reflect the recent legislative changes relating to pollution charges as a supplement to the state budget for financing of national, regional and local environmental programs and measures. Half of the fees paid into the Fund are channelled for national use, while the other half is retained in the fund of the district from which the payment originated. The 1994 draft budget projects revenues to the Fund (including carryover from the prior year) to equal EEK 19.2 million (about US $1.51 million), and expenditures to equal EEK 19.0 million (about US $1.50 million) for a surplus of EEK 200,000 (about US $15,000). 1.9 Estonia is a party to a number of international environmental conventions and treaties. It has signed and ratified the "Convention on the Protection of the Marine Environment of the Baltic Sea Area" (Helsinki Convention), which obligates it to undertake concrete actions to reduce marine pollution from land based sources and to implement a wide range of recommendations on various environmental matters which are developed by the Helsinki Commission (HELCOM) through a process of active input, review and approval by the signatory parties to the Convention. In this context, Estonia has been an active participant in many programs of HELCOM, including the Programme Implementation Task Force (PITF) which is responsible for coordinating implementation of the Baltic Sea Joint Comprehensive Environmental Action Programme (JCP) adopted in 1992. In addition, Estonia has signed and/or ratified a number of international treaties, including the Ramsar, Gdansk, Bern, Bonn and Basel Conventions. Estonia is also active in the Environmental Action Program for Central and Eastern Europe (EAP) and the environmental working groups of the United Nations Economic Council for Europe (UN/ECE). 1.10 Country Environment Policy and Strategy. A new national environmental action plan based on policy reform, institutional strengthening and investment is currently being prepared within the context of the Environmental Action Program for Central and Eastern Europe with support from EU (PHARE). The GOE has identified the following as being some of the most important measures to be taken regarding policy reform: (a) incorporation of environmental considerations into the development of key sectors such as industry, agriculture, transport, etc.; (b) continued development of the environmental taxation system and the Estonian Environmental Fund for financing environmental measures; (c) introduction of a framework for legislative and regulatory mechanisms; (d) promotion of public awareness and participation in the environmental decision making process; and (e) decentralization of environmnental and resource management responsibilities to municipal and local governments. As noted at the "Public Expenditure Conference," the GOE has emphasized the importance of institution building and strengthening as prerequisites for policy development and implementation, especially at the municipal level. It has also requested Bank support for preparation of a "Public Environmental Awareness and Education Program." 1.11 Sector Priorities. Environmental issues are a central concern for the GOE which takes its international environmental commitments seriously. The GOE is committed to improving water resource management in the country and has stated its clear intent to develop new and more effective mechanisms for water pollution control. As was noted at the May 1994 "Public Expenditure Conference," an important element of Estonia's national environmental management strategy is the decentralization of responsibilities for environmental management, with a greater emphasis being placed on the role of municipal and local governments in this area. The GOE intends to give investment priority to
 -4 - environmental projects aimed at improving water supply and wastewater treatment. The ability of the GOE to embark on major public infrastructure investments in the water sector is hampered, however, by the current overall economic situation of the country, making it unlikely that the GOE can undertake such investments without external funding support. 1 .12 Coastal Zone and Protected Areas. Estonia has protected areas covering approximately 7 percent of the total land area. These include 6 state-level reserves, 57 reserves of national significance, 78 reserves of local importance, and 232 landscape elements. The maintenance of these protected areas is becoming increasingly complex due to the problems associated with restoring land to pre-1940 owners, and the government's limited financial capacity to either compensate private owners for loss of land or manage the areas itself. 1.13 Drainage of wetlands for agriculture and exploitation of timber from wet forests is also a cause for concern due to the potential loss of habitat. Unless adequate control measures are adopted, it is possible that wet forests may be drained further to accommodate additional timber harvesting. In addition, the return of land to pre-1940 owners or their heirs may create pressure from small holders for drainage programs to improve agricultural productivity and allow for small scale timber harvesting which would result in a reduction of wetland areas. 1.14 Water and Wastewater Services. Water supply needs of domestic and industrial consumers are primarily met by groundwater supplies in order to avoid using surface waters polluted by dewatering of oil-shale mines, agricultural runoff, and the direct discharge of wastewaters from Estonia's major urban areas into the Gulf of Finland, the eastern Baltic Sea, and the Gulf of Riga. Increased levels of nitrogen and phosphorous in the raw water supply have made the provision of clean drinking water more difficult and costly. In 1993, approximately 13.5 percent of the available drinking water in Estonia failed to meet health standards. The Estonian authorities have increased the use of deep groundwater to minimize the public health risk associated with contaminated surface and shallow groundwater. High levels of bacteriological pollution resulting from discharge of raw sewage and industrial wastewaters into coastal areas have forced the closure of many beaches, including recreationally important beaches near Tallinn, Haapsalu, and Parnu. 1.15 Water consumption in Estonia has been decreasing over the past four years as a result of the accompanying overall economic restructuring process. Total water extraction in Estonia in 1993 was 2.1 billion cubic meters, of which 1.8 billion were consumed. Approximately 80 percent of Estonia's population is connected to the water supply system. 1.16 Estonia's sewerage system covers approximately 80-85 percent of the country's inhabitants and industrial enterprises. However, many of the treatment plants in the system are in very poor condition and offer little or no real treatment of wastewater. Almost all of the existing treatment plants require modernization and rehabilitation. The total amount of wastewater discharged by domestic and industrial consumers in 1993 was estimated at 2.1 billion cubic meters. Of the 393 million cubic meters of wastewater requiring some type of treatment, 370 million cubic meters were treated, though just over half of that amount received only mechanical treatment. As a result, much of Estonia's wastewater is inadequately treated and in some cases, wastewaters are discharged without treatment. 1.17 User charges for water and sewage are set by individual water and wastewater enterprises, but must be approved by their respective city councils. Although water and sewage tariffs have generally risen, they are still inadequate to permit proper maintenance of infrastructure or investment in new assets.
 - 5 - In general, most water and wastewater enterprises have been covering their operating expenses, although non-payment of tariffs, especially by industrial users, has, and continues to be, a serious problem for most cities. Investment costs have been financed by transfers from the state budget. 1.18 In order to implement sound management practices, tariffs would need to be increased by the majority of the country's water and wastewater utilities and collection performance would need to be improved to cover not only operational and maintenance costs but capital costs as well. Strategies for financing the replacement and rehabilitation of old equipment would have to be explored, along with strategies for leakage reduction and improved tariff collection. 1.19 Privatization/Municipalization. Privatization of state-owned property in Estonia is proceeding well with the government moving on several different tracks, but there remain difficult issues to address. A number of enterprises have been privatized. The government has not recommended privatization of the country's water and wastewater enterprises. However, the national government has transferred the plants of the national state-owned water and wastewater administration "Eesti Vesi" (Estonian Water) to the ownership of the respective municipalities as part of the process of decentralization, enabling the municipalities to establish independent municipally-owned companies. Under the Law on Local Government Arrangement (1993), the cities or town councils have the authority to establish taxes and fees (including tariffs for water and wastewater) once responsibility for the enterprise has been transferred. As water and wastewater enterprises are transferred to municipalities, outright privatization of the enterprises, or the establishment of joint ventures or concessional agreements with foreign investors regarding enterprise operation, is possible if the municipality so decides. 1.20 Tourism Development. Estonia's tourism sector has strong potential to attract visitors from abroad. The Hanseatic city of Tallinn with its "Old Town" is currently the most popular tourist attraction, but the university town of Tartu and the coastal spa towns of Parnu and Haapsalu have a long history of attracting foreign tourists. Potential spots for eco-tourism include the Lahemaa National Park, the Matsalu State Nature Reserve (a Ramsar Convention site), and the Estonian Islands Biosphere Reserve. The coastline of Estonia has numerous bays, straits, and over 1,500 islets. There are more than 1,000 inland lakes, large areas of forests, and wild game which has already attracted a number of hunting enthusiasts from other countries. The large Baltic islands of Hiiumaa and Saaremaa, whose populations have preserved their vernacular architecture and cultural traditions, could serve as an additional attraction. 1.21 Statistical data show that tourism has been declining since 1989 when approximately 650,000 tourists visited Estonia. In 1993, that number had decreased to 478,000. However, the proportion of tourists from Western Europe has increased substantially. In 1993, approximately 80 percent of all foreign tourists came from Finland, 10 percent from Sweden, and 4 percent from Germany. Approximately 80 percent of all foreign tourists stay in Estonia for less than one day; however, growing numbers of visitors are going beyond Tallinn and making visits of up to one .veek. In 1993, the Estonian Tourism Board began setting up a registry of accommodation service companies. The registry currently contains 220 different hotels, holiday homes and other similar facilities. From an economic viewpoint, the revitalization and diversification of tourism in the region is important for creation of employment and income generation opportunities in rural settlements which have suffered serious economic dislocations during the restructuring process. There is currently a shortage of tourist accommodations in Tallinn while many hotels, spas, and other facilities in rural areas have trouble attracting visitors. It should be kept in mind, however, that the tourism potential is connected to future environmental conditions, such as the quality of the water of the Baltic Sea and the general aesthetic conditions of the region.
 - 6 - C. The Project Area 1.22 Overview. The Project area includes two scenic bays on the Baltic coast of western Estonia: (a) Haapsalu Bay to the north which is dominated by the historic town of Haapsalu; and (b) Matsalu Bay to the south, featuring Matsalu State Nature Reserve, a site of international significance for migratory birds. These bays are fringed by the islands of Vormsi, Hiiumaa, and Saaremaa, which together create a semi-enclosed area dominated by a variety of terrestrial and marine ecosystems suitable for a range of conservation and recreational uses. In recognition of their regional importance, the JCP identified actions to address the management of wastewater discharges from the Municipality of Haapsalu and management of the ecologically critical Matsalu Bay among the top priority actions to be taken in the context of the Baltic Sea Environment Program. 1.23 Haapsalu. The city of Haapsalu is located on the western coast of Estonia, lying on a long and narrow peninsula that reaches into the sea and divides the Haapsalu Bay into the open Eeslaht and the shallow Tagalaht. It occupies an area of approximately 11 km2 and has a population of about 14,000; non-Estonians make up about 23 percent of the city's population. It is a scenic city dominated by a castle and features extensive districts of historic wooden homes. The city has a major former Soviet air base, but most of the Russian military personnel and their families have left and the air field is currently not used. Haapsalu has no major industries, but has strong potential to reclaim and develop its historical position as a major tourist resort, which was a summer spa of the Russian imperial family. In addition, the marine environment of Haapsalu contains deposits of curative mud which has economic value, both in the domestic market as well as for export. The mud is used for medical purposes in the treatment of rheumatism and nerve diseases in arms and legs. The biologically active substances present in the mud have also been used in veterinary medicine, cosmetics, and fertilizers. At present, mud is taken only from one of two deposits closest to town. It is this deposit which stands to benefit most from improved wastewater treatment. Eco-tourism could be developed in both Haapsalu Bay and the adjacent Matsalu Bay, both of which have rich and diverse wildlife. 1.24 Haapsalu Water Works. The Haapsalu Water Works (HWW) serves about 2/3 of the area's 14,000 residents and associated small industries. The ownership of the utility has just recently been transferred from the national water and wastewater administration Eesti Vesi, to the Municipality of Haapsalu (MOH). The MOH has formed HWW to a municipal enterprise in accordance with the Law on Municipal Enterprises. The legal process was finalized February 10, 1995. HWW has characteristics comrnon to many water and wastewater utilities in Central and Eastern Europe, including management and administration. It has a small core staff of committed management who are seeking to change their utility to make it function better and to gain greater access to resources for investment. The enterprise's financial source are the tariffs collected for water and sewage services. 1.25 Water Supply and Levels of Service. Water supply services in Haapsalu are currently acceptable both in delivery and in health standards. The reliability of the equipment in the pumping stations, however, is questionable and the supply of spare parts erratic. It is necessary to replace almost half the pumps each year, resulting in excessive maintenance costs. The large number of historic wooden houses creates special water supply requirements for fire fighting services. 1.26 The water supply for Haapsalu is taken from groundwater sources via twelve wells offering a total water supply of 9,600 m3/day. The length of Haapsalu's water network, together with that of Uuemoisa, is 33 km. All larger buildings are connected to the network, but many private households take water from one of the city's 52 street hydrants, or from shallow hand pump wells. Water

The average household water consumption is estimated at 140 liter per capita. Matsalu Bay lies approximately 20 km to the south of the city of Haapsalu and drains a catchment of some 3,200 km2 which is mostly agricultural in nature. Only the two small towns of Rapla and Lihula lie in the catchment, along with approximately 10 smaller settlements and former state farms. However, due to the extensive area of the drainage basin, the total population isaround 40,000. Matsalu Bay is included in the HELCOM list of "priority hot-spots" for Estonia, because of its international and regional importance as a wetland and nature reserve. 1.31 The shoreline of Matsalu Bay is extremely intricate and there are over ten islets in the bay itself. The diverse nature of the flora has resulted in the development of a unique variety of habitats, especially for migrating and breeding birds. The area is important for international scientific research, and is the center for the Estonian bird ringing program. The bay is one of the stopping areas on the Baltic portion of the East African-European-Arctic flyway for migratory birds and is a critical part of a complex system of coastal wildlife habitats which includes Lake Pape in Latvia and the Nemunas Delta in Lithuania. 1.32 The Matsalu wetland is being negatively affected by drainage from the wet meadows of the Kasari River, pollution from surrounding cattle farms, accelerating eutrophication from catchment run-off, and by inadequately controlled sport fishing from motor boats. The main problem is organic enrichment and eutrophication which results in the expansion of the area of reed beds in the bay (approximately 60 hectares annually). This alters sedimentation and habitat distribution, thereby affecting

The nutrient enrichment trend has abated somewhat in recent years, as the rising costs of fertilizers has led to a decrease in their use. However, the communal and agro-industrial point-source pollution from nearby Lihula and other area communities continues to be a significant contributor to the nutrient load in the bay. 1.33 Protected Areas. The Matsalu State Nature Reserve was created in 1957 and covers an area of approximately 48,000 hectares including part of Matsalu Bay and the Kasari River delta. The nearest town, Lihula (population 1,900), is located three kilometers to the south. Due to its strategic location along the East African-European-Arctic flyway, the Reserve was designated as a site of international significance to migratory birds under the Ramsar Convention in 1976. Bird life, semi-natural plant communities, flood plains, reed beds, coastal and wooded meadows are considered the Reserve's chief environmental assets. Birds depend on both the vegetation and the waters for nesting, feeding, resting and molting. Some 259 species of birds have been recorded at the Reserve, and millions of birds are believed to migrate through the Reserve annually. In addition, 48 mammal species and 40 fish species have been recorded in the Reserve. The wetland also has the potential to be a locally important economic resource, as the reeds can be sold domestically for thatching or to the Nordic countries and Germany for use as traditional roofing material. The present annual harvest is worth approximately EEK 500,000 (US$40,000 equivalent) and provides off-season employment to local farmers. 1.34 Effective management of the Matsalu Reserve faces several challenges. Maintenance of the coastal meadows requires constant human intervention to prevent junipers and other opportunistic species from invading and making the meadows less attractive to migrating birds. Pollution of the Kasari River from agricultural runoff and insufficiently treated wastewaters degrades the quality of the bay's waters and alters the natural habitats for a number of species. The resources available to the GOE for maintenance of this important wetland, however, are limited. The Matsalu Nature Reserve Administration is a state institution directly subordinate to the Ministry of Environment. In past years it employed up to 70 people, but budget cuts in the past few years have reduced the staff to 30 employees, including four researchers and five rangers. Project Origin and Fornulation 2.1 In 1974, the countries of the Baltic Sea region signed the "Convention on the Protection of the Marine Environment of the Baltic Sea Area" in Helsinki. This convention, commonly referred to as the Helsinki Convention, was the first international regional seas agreement and created a framework for regional environmental cooperation. To accelerate the rate of progress in improving national and regional environmental conditions, the Prime Ministers of Sweden and Poland jointly hosted the "Baltic Sea Environment Conference" held in September 1990, in Ronneby, Sweden with participation at the Prime Ministerial level. The conference included senior level participation by the Bank and resulted in the establishment of the Baltic Sea Environment Task Force, comprised of representatives of the riparian states of the Baltic Sea drainage basin, European Commission and international financial institutions, with selected technical organizations and nongovernmental organizations participating as observers. The Task Force, working under HELCOM, based in Helsinki, and with significant participation from the Bank, prepared the JCP. This program, which was adopted by the Ministers of Environment of the Baltic Sea region in April 1992, identified a series of priority actions concerning policies and legislation, actions for the control of point and non-point source pollution, measures for the management of coastal lagoons and wetlands as well as institutional strengthening and human resources development to be undertaken as elements of a long-term regional environmental program. 2.2 Haapsalu and Matsalu State Nature Reserve were ranked by the Task Force as a priority "hot spot" and subsequently by Estonian authorities as a high priority for national and foreign investment in environmental protection. This position has been taken repeatedly by the GOE in a variety of international fora, most recently by the MOE at the May 1994 Bank-sponsored "Public Investment Conference" held in Paris. The Task Force also identified the need to undertake actions for coastal zone management and the conservation of coastal lagoons and wetlands as key elements of the long-term program which provides for a synergetic impact to investments in wastewater management. Conducting such activities in the Haapsalu and Matsalu regions has been strongly supported by the MOE, given its interest in promoting the high ecological, tourism, and recreational values of the areas. 2.3 The proposed Project is intended by the MOE to serve as a "model project" to demonstrate complementary actions for management of point source pollution from secondary cities, small settlements and small enterprises, and non-point source pollution from agriculture and rural areas. A principal reason for the selection of the immediately adjacent Haapsalu and Matsalu Bays as a project area was to have a range of interventions concentrated in a small geographic region which would also have significant short-term impact on areas of high ecological and touristic value. The strategy of the MOE is to have the proposed Project provide a technical and management framework for an effective application of funds from diverse sources to maximize environmental benefits. These benefits would be reduced if funds were used at a variety of separate locations. 2.4 The proposed Project would be the first Bank-supported investment project for improvement of environmental quality undertaken by the GOE. With regard to the WWIC, there is a limited risk that Project implementation would encounter delays due to limited experience in the use of international procurement procedures. In addition, given the limited technical experience with actual costs for implementation of water and wastewater improvements in post-Soviet Estonia, the volatility of local price changes, and previous lack of construction activities to international standards in this sector, construction costs may be underestimated. In order to minimize these risks, the Project would provide for the establishment of a strong PIU, adoption of conservative approaches to cost estimation combined with appropriate physical and price contingencies, and provision of significant technical and procurement support from Bank staff during supervision both from headquarters and the regional office. 5.14 On the basis of previous Bank experience in Eastern Europe there is also a risk that the GOE and cooperating local governments may have problems with the timely provision of local currency support and availability of adequately qualified personnel for Project management, the latter due to government limits on salaries paid to civil servants. These risks would be reduced through close supervision and quick actions to address these types of implementation problems should they occur. 5.15 Institutional and Financial. On the institutional and financial side, the main risks would be the commitment of the Haapsalu City Council to allow the HWW to function as an independent utility which, interalia, may interfere with HWW's ability to adjust tariffs sufficiently to cover its costs, including the repayment of the Bank Loan. These risks can only be partially mitigated through Project supervision, as MOH is an independent body subject to political and social pressures. MOH can be made aware of the consequence of its decisions on tariffs through the dialogue afforded by supervision, the tariff study, and the requested presentation of annual HWW budgets. That MOH jointly with HWW signs the GOE's subsidiary loan agreement will serve to lower the risk of significant deviations from a rational tariff policy. 5.16 Technology and Management. The WWIC technology is standard and involves no unusual risks. The main risk is the utility's financial and institutional capability, requiring substantial strengthening of its financial and managerial capability. Experience with other municipal water and wastewater authorities in transitional economies demonstrates that close Project supervision and adequate technical assistance mitigate these risks. The proposed technologies to be demonstrated under the EMC for the control of point and non-point source pollution from small settlements and agriculture are simple, and have been tested under similar conditions in the Nordic countries and North America. The use of ecological engineering methods would allow for the adaptation of a variety of low-cost methods, including constructed wetlands, under Estonian conditions. A number of Estonian environmental specialists, associated with both applied research and consulting firms, have knowledge of these technologies and some demonstration work has already been undertaken by specialists from Tartu University. 5.17 The principal risks for the EMC concern: (a) difficulties in coordination of activities between various national, local, non-governmental, and consultant organizations; (b) resistance from local authorities and residents to proposed land use control measures to be included in the catchment area and Matsalu State Nature Reserve management plans; (c) a reluctance of local authorities and agriculturalists to adopt new low-cost technologies for the control of pollution; and (d) unanticipated problems associated with the complex issues of restitution of lands confiscated by the State during the Soviet period to their pre-1940 owners.

HWW was established as a municipally owned water and wastewater enterprise in February, 1995 as a part of GOE's broad strategy to decentralize muncipal services. Analysis of HWW's financial statements for the years 1991-1993 shows that the tariff levels were so low in 1991 that the state intervened with subvention of operating expenses; in 1992, tariff levels were increased to a level sufficient enough to cover its cash operating costs and to a small extent a provision for planned maintenance. In 1993, tariffs were increased but not to a level sufficient enough to cover inflation; the utility consequently experienced a deficit. Had the accounts properly accounted for charges for other non-cash items, including a provision for bad and doubtful debts, and proper asset depreciation reflecting replacement costs revaluation, deficits would have been reported for the whole 1991-1993 period. Preliminary 1994 numbers show HWW made minimal profits, though again with an undervalued depreciation. HWW's financial performance for the 1991-1993 period is summarized in Table 9. 48. Historically, GOE has provided financing for all of HWW's capital investment program. Consequently, the enterprise has no long term external debt. Toward the end of 1993 and in early 1994, the financial viability of HWW was hampered by the the transfer of state residential, commercial and industrial properties to the private sector, which has neglected outstanding liabilities of previous owners who failed to pay their bills. Additionally, industries in Haapsalu have experienced financial downturns and consequently regard payment of water bills to be low priority. 49. HWW's inability during the past three years to adjust tariffs in a timely manner to compensate for inflation, to make proper provisions for future investment and maintenance needs, and to compensate for increasing non-payment by consumers has deprived the utility of cash to run its day-to- day operations, let alone provide for future investments. 50.  ANNEX I Page 36 51. Tariff Levels and Revenues. Water tariffs are currently inadequate to cover full operating and depreciation costs. Despite several tariff increases in the last few years, increases have not, since 1992, kept pace with the high and erratic periods of inflation and thus have failed to adjust properly to real cost increases. The tariff structure does not include standing charges (only a symbolic connection fee is said to be charged) nor incremental charges for higher levels of consumption. All tariffs are either of a simple volumetric form or, as is the case for industrial discharges, of a weighted volumetric form. Industrial customers are metered, as are approximately 95 percent of domestic customers. Wastewater tariffs are generally applied on the basis of consumed (metered or estimated) water, rather than accurate sewerage metering. The only exceptions are those for large industrial customers which use considerable volumes of water in the production process, for which a revised "return rate" is agreed, or for those who possess their own water supply, in which case the private supply is metered and a "reduced" charge calculated. In the institutional strengthening component, consisting of the twinning arrangement, assistance for tariff planning and financial operations would be provided based on the results of the tariff study (see TOR, Annex 3B). 52. Billing and Collection. HWW's billing and collection procedures are only partly computerized; consumers are divided into: (a) residential customers; and (b) industrial consumers (including schools, hospitals, offices and shops). At present, residential and industrial customers pay the same tariff. HWW formerly differentiated between households and industry for wastewater fees. Since 1994, however, the base fee is the same for both kinds of users. 53. The collection process is administratively burdensome but has so far been adequate given that the debt ratio does not exceed 10 percent of average total revenues.  Annex 4 WATER AND WASTEWATER IMPROVEMENT COMPONENT ENVIRONMENTAL ASPECTS

 ANNEX 4 Page 1 REPUBLIC OF ESTONIA HAAPSALU AND MATSALU BAYS ENVIRONMENT PROJECT WATER AND WASTEWATER IMPROVEMENT COMPONENT ENVIRONMENTAL ASPECTS A. Overview 1. Introduction. Implementation of the Water and Wastewater Improvement Component (WWIC) of the proposed Project is anticipated to have positive environmental benefits in the Haapsalu Bay area through improved water supply, major expansion of wastewater collection, significant improvements in the performance standards of the municipal wastewater treatment plant and improved sludge managemiienit. This will improve public health, ecology, water quality and aesthetic conditions in Haapsalu Bay, provide protection of curative muds found in the Bay and reduce pollution of the Baltic Sea. The proposed Plroject would not involve involuntary resettlement and is not anticipated to have an impact on known archaeological or historical sites in Haapsalu or the Matsalu State Nature Reserve. 2. Enviromnental Review. The proposed Project component was the subject of a site specific environmental review prepared by SWECO (Sweden), in association with Eesti Projekt (Estonia), and Bohlin & Stromberg AB (Sweden). The review complies with the Estonian "Order on Carrying Out Environmental Impact Assessment (Government Regulation 13.11.92)" and is consistent with the provisions for a Category B project under World Bank Operational Directive 4.01, "'Environmlental Assessment." The objective was to evaluate the potential environmental impacts from the rehabilitation and expansion of water and wastewater facilities of the Haapsalu Water Works (HWW). These activities would be implemented by HWW with the support of the Estonian Ministry of Envirolnment, Municipality of Haapsalu, Governments of Sweden and Finland and the World Bank. 3. Consultation Process. The environmental review for the proposed Project was prepared with the full cooperation of the Estonian Ministry of Environment and the Laane County Environmental Department. Representatives of the MOE and its Environmental Assessment Board have been involved in all stages of development of the proposed Project and have participated in a series of site visits to all proposed Project sites. Consultations have been conducted with the representatives of Laane County and the local municipalities. 4. Present Conditions. (a) Water Supply. Although there are few impacts associated with the existing potable water system, the capacity of the existing water reservoirs is too small to meet the requirements of flow equalization and water supply during emergency situations. The current capacity is 300m3, well below the estimated minimum capacity of 1200m3 that would be required. Being able to cope with peak rates of flow for fire-fighting is especially important for Haapsalu because of the predominance of historical wooden structures in the center of the town which is a major asset for tourism.
 ANNEX 4 Page 2 (b) Wastewater Collection. The length of the sewage system in Haapsalu is 20km, and in the adjoining settlements of Uuemoisa and Parlepa, 6km. There are 13 pumping stations in Haapsalu's sewage system which convey wastewater to a treatment plant equipped to perform mechanical treatment. In Uuemoisa there are 4 pumping stations. The infiltration of groundwater into the concrete, ceramic and asbestos-cement pipelines of the sewage system is significant, resulting in both excess loading of the treatment plant and pollution of local groundwater. (c) Wastewater Treatment and Disposal. The main environmental problems associated with current HWW operations concern the discharge of partially and untreated effluent and the disposal of sewage sludge. Currently most of the municipal wastewater of Haapsalu is treated at a mechanical treatment plant in which the reduction of oxygen consuming material and nutrients is poor. The existing wastewater treatment plant is in very poor condition. The following problems have been noted at the plant: (i) control of plant performance is weak; (ii) grit chambers have not been in operation for several years due to operational problems; (iii) primary sedimentation basins are working with a heterogeneous load as the inflow to the treatment plant from the main pumping station is periodical; (iv) raw sludge is occasionally discharged from the primary sedimentation basins; (v) drainage of the sludge composting area is erratic, allowing for water accumulation during rainy periods; and (vi) analyses of treated wastewater are performed once a month in the Eesti Vesi laboratory in Tallinn as the local laboratory is not operating. Microbiological loading to the receiving waters is high, and advisory notices against swimming have been posted at the beaches near the town. The outfall pipe discharges directly into a reed bed at the shoreline and it has been observed that environmental conditions in the area have worsened in recent years. Problems associated with this discharge are exacerbated by the fact that the treatment works is unable to provide full secondary treatment to the capacity of sewage entering the system. Total average wastewater flow to the treatment plant (calculated from measured water consumption) is 5500 m3/d. In rainy periods, the flow to the treatment plant is 1,000 m3 an hour. Currently partly treated or untreated wastewater is discharged at a number of different locations throughout the Haapsalu area. This has ecological, aesthetic, health, and economic implications. The curative muds, used for external and internal health treatments, are a prime tourist attraction of Haapsalu. The muds are formed naturally in the shallow waters of the Bay and constitute a unique resource which is threatened by pollution. (d) Wastewater Treatment Plant Site. The upgrading of the wastewater treatment plant involves construction of buildings and process tanks at a large site established in 1962 in an area designated for industrial and warehouse/storage facilities. There is no problem with housing being close to the plant site or inconsistent proposed future land use in the area. Significant space is available at the site for expansion of the facilities. 5. Major Findings. The environmental review concluded that the wastewater treatment plant is currently hydraulically overloaded. Extending the works to treat a greater volume of wastewater would prevent untreated and partially treated sewage being discharged into Haapsalu Bay and the Baltic Sea.
 ANNEX 4 Page 3 After upgrading and expansion of the sewage collection network and reconstruction and expansion of the wastewater treatment plant, pollution discharged to the Bay and the Sea would be decline significantly due to reduced infiltration, elimination of the local discharge outlets and improved treatment efficiency. The leakage of sewage to the surrounding soil through worn-out sewers is a possible threat to the quality of groundwater. Works aimed at the reconstruction of these sewers must be given a high priority to reduce excessive loads to the wastewater treatment plant and groundwater pollution. In addition, the sludge treatment process needs to be improved to: (a) reduce the volume of sludge; (b) improve the drainability of the sludge; (c) stabilize the organic matter; (d) reduce the odor; and (e) destroy or at least control pathogenic organisms. 6. It is apparent that point source pollution within Haapsalu is a major problem for water quality. In addition to lowering the quality of the receiving waters, thus damaging aquatic ecosystems and the curative muds, the discharges of untreated sewage are resulting in unacceptable microbiological pollution. Collection and conveyance of these untreated discharges to the treatment plant and provision of the appropriate capacity at the utility to treat them is a priority. The infiltration of surface water into the system increases the amount of water to be transferred to the treatment plant thus contributing to the hydraulic overload of the plant. As the volume of pollution discharged from a treatment plant is related to the wastewater flow, a reduced flow of wastewater will mean a reduction in the volume of pollution discharged into the sea. B. Elements of the Proposed Project Component 7. Proposed Improvements. A brief description of proposed water supply and wastewater treatment improvements in Haapsalu is provided as follows: (a) Water Supply. Improvements to the water supply system can be divided into two distinct categories: those to maintain the current system and improvements aimed at enhancing the performance of the system. (i) Operations to Maintain the Current System. The following operations to maintain the current system are proposed: * Renovation or exchange of the well pumps; and * Centralizing control of the crucial water supply pumps for optimization of the pumping pattern; (ii) Improvements Aimed at Enhancing Performance. The following improvements aimed at enhancing performance of the water supply system are proposed: * Construction of a secondary pumping station with a capacity of 600m3/h and water reservoirs of 2 x 1000m3; * Construction of pipes from existing bore wells to the reservoirs;
 ANNEX 4 Page 4 * Construction of the main pipeline from the secondary pumping to the water network; and * Completion of the construction of bore-well pumping station No. 10; (b) Wastewater Treatment. Improvements to the wastewater system can be divided into two distinct categories: those to maintain the current system and improvements aimed at enhancing the performance of the system. (i) Operations to Maintain the Current System. The following operations are proposed to maintain the current system: * Reconstruction of worn-out sewers and the existing pressure pipelines; * Reconstruction of the pumping stations at Kastani and Aianduse Streets; and * Improvement of the performance of the main pumping station by replacing the single pump with two smaller pumps and the installation of frequency regulated drives in the pumps; (ii) Improvements Aimed at Enhancing Performance. The following operations to enhance the performance of the system are proposed: * Elimination of the wastewater discharges to the sea inside the town area, including: - the Kreutzwaldi outlet; - the Auto Service outlets; - the Kiltsi road outlets; - the Uuemoisa outlets; - the Supluse Street outlet; and - the Hako outlets. 8. Potential Environmental Impacts. The environmental impacts which may result from the proposed WWIC have been divided into general impacts and specific impacts: (a) General Impacts. There will inevitably be some environmental impacts associated with the construction activities. The magnitude of these activities will depend on a number of factors including proximity of housing, length of construction period, working hours, and methods of construction but, in the case of large construction projects (e.g., extension of the wastewater treatment plant), they have the potential to be locally significant and prolonged. In particular such impacts could include noise and vibration, dust releases, possible odor releases when working on existing sewage facilities, pollution of surface or underground waters due to releases or spillages of material from construction sites, disruption of traffic and noise pollution associated with transporting construction materials and large items of plant, pollution risk and hazard to the health of construction workers
 ANNEX 4 Page 5 if construction is carried out on contaminated land (e.g., areas where HWW sewage sludge has been stored). Visual environmental impacts are expected to be minimal and no impacts are anticipated to historic structures. None of the water or wastewater treatment proposals involve any resettlement of people. (b) Specific Impacts of Potential Water Treatment and Supply Improvement Schemes. The particular impacts can be divided into two distinct categories: those to maintain the current system and improvements aimed at enhancing the performance of the system. (i) Operations to Maintain the Current System. Renovation and replacement of pumps to optimize performance would improve the efficiency of the units and lead to energy and cost savings. (ii) Improvements to Enhance System Performance. There would be no negative environmental impacts due to the proposed waterlines. The waterlines will enable the system to cope much more effectively with peak rates of flow which is of utmost importance for fire-fighting. The historic wooden buildings in the center of Haapsalu add to the significance of this positive impact. (c) Specific Impacts of Potential Wastewater Improvement Proposals. The particular impacts can be divided into those resulting from operations to maintain the current system and improvements to enhance system performance. (i) Operations to Maintain the Current System. Undertaking operations to maintain the current wastewater system can be expected to have an overall positive environmental impact. Replacing, repairing, and renovating sewers, mechanical and electrical equipment, and sewage works plant would minimize future failures and thus reduce the risk of discharge of untreated or partially treated sewage. These actions would improve water quality and be of benefit to public health. The reconstruction of worn-out sewers would have a positive impact as the leakage of sewage to the surrounding soil and groundwater table would be eliminated. Upgrading pumping stations to improve efficiency would save energy and reduce costs. (ii) Improvements to Enhance System Performance. Improvements to enhance the performance of the wastewater collection and treatment system would also have an overall positive impact on Estonia's environment, as described below: * Providing sewerage for currently unsewered areas can be expected to improve groundwater and surface water quality as cesspools would no longer be required in those areas; * Diversion and interception of domestic and industrial wastewater, which is currently discharged to Haapsalu Bay untreated, and providing suitable treatment facilities would have an overwhelmingly positive impact on the Haapsalu environment. The curative muds would be protected from contamination by wastewater;
 ANNEX 4 Page 6 * Extension of the Haapsalu wastewater treatment plant to treat a greater volume of sewage would alleviate the current plant overload which would improve effluent quality and thus enhance the chemical and microbiological quality of Haapsalu Bay and adjoining areas of the Baltic Sea. Pollution loads of BOD7, total phosphorus and suspended solids would be drastically reduced. In order to gain the maximum environrmental benefit, such an extension should also provide sufficient capacity to treat the volume of sewage expected from newly sewered areas; * In general, noise pollution from the new machinery is not a problem. Blowers for the aeration of sewage would be placed indoors to prevent noise emissions; and The proposed sludge treatment process would generate less odor emissions than the present one. Emissions from the new aeration tank would be small. The new receiving station for septic sludge, however, may at times generate heavy odors and should be designed for later connection to a biofilter if deemed necessary. 9. Proposed Mitigation Plan. The overall aim of the proposed Project is to implement measures which would improve the water supply and wastewater services of HWW. The major environmental impact of the Project would result from the improvement in surface and groundwater quality in the Project area resulting in improved ecological conditions. 10. Few of the impacts of the completed Project would be adverse and none are likely to be significant and require mitigation. The impact of construction would be largely limited to relatively minor disruption and disturbance. Nevertheless, it should still be possible to reduce the extent of this inconvenience by implementing some relatively straightforward measures to minimize these impacts through clear requirements in the construction contracts combined with good construction supervision. 11 Proposed Monitoring Plan. Routine monitoring of water and wastewater for purposes of system management is the responsibility of HWW. To support these activities, the Project includes support for rehabilitation and enhancement of laboratory equipment. This would provide the means to optimize plant performance and to maintain a stable and reliable operational monitoring plan. Overall environmental monitoring is the responsibility of the Ministry of Environment which is currently revising its national monitoring program on the basis of recommendations from a study jointly conducted by the United States Environmental Protection Agency and EU PHARE. It is proposed that data on water quality, biological aspects, and contamination of sediments be collected prior to the commencement of any works. The monitoring program would be continued as a routine element of the local environmental monitoring program to assess the impacts of the various improvement measures and compare with the baseline situation to determine the impacts that occur and their significance. 12. Institutional Strengthening and Human Resources Development. The proposed Project includes use of a "twinning arrangement" to support institutional strengthening and human resources development activities for HWW. These activities would include training for HWW personnel in the collection, analysis and application of water and wastewater monitoring to the operation of the utility.

doc.abstracts: The Haapsalu and Matsalu Bays Environment Project will be implemented over four years as an environmental management project for the coastal area of western Estonia. It will consist of a Water and Wastewater Improvement Component (WWIC) and an Environmental Management Component (EMC). The WWIC will consist of: a) rehabilitation and expansion of the Haapsalu water and wastewater system, including equipment and works along with engineering services; and b) institutional strengthening and training to assist in establishing an autonomous and financially independent water and wastewater utility in Haapsalu. This will include assistance for tariff restructuring/tariff planning and financial operations. The EMC will consist of: a) technical and financial support through the Ministry of Environment (MOE) for the implementation of selected elements of the Management Plan for Matsalu State Nature Reserve by coordinating and providing funding for identified investments such as access roads, observation towers, and information boards; b) design and implementation of a program of cost-effective activities to reduce point and non-point source pollution of Matsalu Bay from small settlements and agriculture; and c) support for planning and management of eco-tourism.
